title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: intolerable.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Again, if considerations of social utility limit creative activity, the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: creations of such activity must be meagre in nature. Spiritual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: creativeness is most fruitful when it is concerned with tasks that are
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: attempted for their intrinsic value, and is not fettered by the thought
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of their usefulness to society.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: It is, too, a dangerous thing to look for truth in the opinion of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: majority, for this is such a changing phenomenon that only a part, at
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: most, can be permanent truth. The course of history has taught us, too,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that great ideas have come to individuals and have been rejected by the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: masses for long periods of time.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The immediate effect of the failure of socialism is the encouragement of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: _individualism_, for indeed some of the arguments against the former are
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: arguments in favour of the latter. Individualism opens up a new life, a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: life which is free, joyous, and unconventional.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: But can individualism give a meaning and value to life as a whole? Man
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: cannot from his own resources produce a high ideal which compels him to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: fight for higher development, and it is not possible for him from an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: individualistic standpoint to regard himself as a manifestation of a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: larger life. His whole life must be spent in the improvement of his own
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: condition. Even in the case of strongly marked personalities, they can
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: never get beyond themselves and their own subjective states, for they
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: must always live upon themselves, and eternally reflect upon their own
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: doings.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: But such a view of life cannot satisfy man; he is a contemplative being,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and he must find some all-inclusive whole, of which he is a part. If he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: fails to find it, life for him must become a blank, and he must fall a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: prey to boredom and satiety. Man's life is not to be confined to his own
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: particular sphere, his life must extend far beyond that--he must concern
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: himself with the infinite in the universe; "He must view life--nay,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: more, he must live it--in the light of this larger whole." A life based
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: upon individualism then, will seem, even in the case of strong
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: personalities, to be extremely narrow. How much more so will this be
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: true of the ordinary man, who takes little interest in his own
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: individuality, or pleasure in its development?
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Thus it is that both forms of humanistic culture--socialism and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: individualism--fail to give a real meaning to life. "Socialistic culture
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: directs itself chiefly to the outward conditions of life, but in care
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: for these it neglects life itself." Individualistic culture, on the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: other hand, endeavours to deal with life itself, but fails to see life
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: as a whole, or as possessing any real inwardness.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Both types of culture are apt to deceive themselves in regard to their
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: own emptiness, because, unconsciously, they make more out of man than is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: consistent with their assumptions. "They presuppose a spiritual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: atmosphere as a setting for our human life and effort. In the one case,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: this cementing of a union between individuals appears to set free the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: springs of love and truth; in the other, each single unit seems to have
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: behind it the background of a spiritual world whose development is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: fostered by means of its individual labour." In this way life acquires
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in both cases a meaning, but it does so only by departing from both
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: positions, and taking up what is, at least partly, an idealistic
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: position.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The theories, too, can only be made really plausible by idealising man
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to an unwarrantable extent. The socialist assumes that a change of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: material surroundings will be immediately followed by a change in the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: character of man, and that men will work happily together for the sake
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of the community. The individualist asks us to believe that man is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: naturally noble and highminded, and cares only for the higher and better
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: things. But experience, says Eucken, does not justify us in placing so
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: much faith in humanity. "Do we not see the great masses of our
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: population possessed by a passion that sweeps all before it, a reckless
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: spirit of aggressiveness, a disposition to lower all culture to the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: level of their interests and comprehension--evincing the while a defiant
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: self-assertion? And on the side of individualism, what do we see? Paltry
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: meanness in abundance, embroidered selfishness, idle self-absorption,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the craving to be conspicuous at all costs, repulsive hypocrisy, lack of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: courage despite all boastful talk, a lukewarm attitude towards all
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: spiritual tasks, but the busiest industry when personal advantage is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: concerned."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The theories of socialism and individualism can never be adequate
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: explanations of the great problem of life, for life cannot have a real
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: meaning if man cannot strive towards some lofty aim far higher than
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: himself, and such a goal the two humanistic theories do not provide for
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: him.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Religion, Idealism, Naturalism, Socialism, Individualism, while calling
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: attention to important facts in life, all fail in themselves to form
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: adequate theories to explain life. We have given the main outlines of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Eucken's arguments, but such a brief summary cannot do justice to his
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: excellent evaluations of these theories--these the reader may find in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: his own works.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: CHAPTER III
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: ANOTHER SEARCH FOR TRUTH
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The result of the inquiry into the solutions of the problem offered in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the past is to show that they are all inadequate to explain and to give
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: an ideal to the whole of life. Perplexed as to the truth of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: existence of a higher world, man looked to the natural world for a firm
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: basis to life. Here he failed to find rest--rather, indeed, he found
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: less security than he had previously felt, for did not naturalism make
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of him a mere unconscious mechanism, and deny the very existence of his
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: soul? Then he turned to humanity, and the opposing tendencies of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: socialism and individualism came into evidence. Each hindered the other,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: each shook his traditional beliefs, and each failed to give him a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: satisfactory goal for life. Socialism concerned itself with external
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: social relations, but it gave life no soul. Then individualism confined
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: man to his own resources, and there resulted an inner hollowness which
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: became painfully evident. Socialism and individualism fail to provide a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: sure footing. Instead of finding certainty, man has fallen into a still
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: deeper state of perplexity.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: What shall he do? Must he once again leave the realistic systems of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Naturalism, Socialism, and Individualism, and return to the older
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: systems of Religion and Idealism? Was he not wrong in giving up the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: thought of a higher invisible world? Has not the restriction of life to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the visible world robbed life of its greatness and dignity? This it
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: certainly has done, and there is little wonder that the soul of mankind
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is already revolting, and shows a tendency once again to look towards
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: religion and idealism for a solution of life.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: But the educated mind can never again take up exactly the same position
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: as it once did in regard to religion and idealism. The great realistic
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: theories have made too great a change in the standard of life, and in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: man himself, to make it possible for him to revert simply to the old
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: conditions, and the older orthodox doctrines of religion can never again
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: be accepted as a mere matter of course. But the great question has again
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: come to the forefront--is there a higher world, or is the fundamental
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: truth of religion a mere illusion? This is the question that calls for
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: answer to-day, an answer which must be different, as man is different,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: from the answers that were given in the past. A satisfactory answer is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: impossible without understanding clearly the relation between the Old
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and the New, and without taking account of the great, if partial, truths
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that the realistic schemes of life have taught mankind.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: To accept unreservedly Naturalism, Socialism, and Individualism is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: impossible, for these rob life of its deeper meaning. To return to the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: older doctrines without reserve is equally impossible.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Shall we ignore the question? This would be a fatal mistake. Some throw
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: themselves into the rush of work, and endeavour to forget the deeper
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: problems of life--but "the result is a life all froth and shimmer,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: lacking inward sincerity, a life that can never in itself satisfy them,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: but only keep up the appearance of doing so." There must be some
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: decision; for is not society being more and more broken up into small
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: sections, possessing the most variable standards of life, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: evaluating things in a diversity of ways? Such an inward schism must
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: weaken any effort on the part of humanity to combine for ideal ends.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Perhaps he of narrow vision, who sees nothing in life but sensuous
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: pleasure, is happy--but it is the happiness of the lower world. Perhaps,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: too, he of the superficial mind is happy, who sees no deep
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: contradictions in the solutions offered, and is prepared to accept one
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to-day and another tomorrow--but his happiness is that of the feeble
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: mind.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: What then can be done? Shall we despair? Never! The question is far too
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: urgent. To despair is to accept a policy that spells disaster to the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: human race. The immediate environment is powerless to give life any real
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: meaning. We must probe deeper into the eternal--and it is from such
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: investigations that Eucken outlines a new theory of life.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: But before we proceed to deal with Eucken's contribution to the problem,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: it will be profitable to stay awhile to consider how it is that we can
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: obtain truth at all, and what are the tests that we can apply to truth
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: when we think we have attained it. It is the problem of the possibility
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of knowledge, really, that we have to discuss in brief. Eucken himself
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: does not pay much direct attention to this difficult question, for, as
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: has been already pointed out, he refuses to be drawn from his main
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: problem. It is impossible, however, to appreciate Eucken without
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: understanding clearly the position he takes up in this matter.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: What is truth? How can we know?--these are entrancing problems for the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: profound thinker, and have been written upon frequently and at great
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: length. But we can do little more at present than give the barest
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: outline of the positions that have been taken up. Every search for truth
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: must assume a certain position in this matter; in studying Eucken's
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: philosophy it is of the first importance--more so perhaps than in the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: case of most other philosophers--to keep in mind clearly from the outset
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the position he implicitly assumes.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The simplest theory of knowledge is that of _Empiricism_, which holds
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that all knowledge must be gained through experience of the outside
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: world, and of our mental states. We see a blue wall, we obtain through
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: our eyes an impression of blueness, and are able to make a statement:
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: "This wall is blue." This, of course, is one of the simplest assertions
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that can be made, and consists merely in assigning a term--"blue"--the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: meaning of which has already been agreed upon, to a colour that we
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: appear to see on a wall. The test of the truth of this assertion is a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: simple one--it is true if it corresponds with fact. If the same
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: assertion is made in regard to a red wall, then it is obviously untrue.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Our sense impressions give rise to a great variety of such expressions.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: We state "the wall is blue" as a result of an impression obtained
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: through the organs of sight; then we speak of a pungent smell, a sweet
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: taste, a harsh sound, or a rough stone, on account of impressions
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: received respectively through the organs of smell, taste, hearing, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: touch. But, of course, all such assertions are superficial in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: character--there is little more in them than the application of a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: conventional term to an observed phenomenon, they avail us little in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: solving the mysteries of the universe.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Strictly speaking, this is for the empiricist the limit of possible
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: knowledge, but he would be a poor investigator who would be content with
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: this and no more. The empiricist tries to go a distinct step in advance
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of this. The scientist observing the path of a planet travelling round
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the sun, finds that its course is that of an ellipse. He studies the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: path of a second planet, and finds that this also travels along an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: elliptical orbit. Later he finds that all planets he is able to observe
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: travel in the same kind of path--then he hazards a general statement,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and says, "All planets travel round their suns in elliptical orbits."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: But now he has left the realm of certainty for that of uncertainty.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: There may be innumerable planets which he cannot observe that take a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: different course. He hazards the general statement, because he assumes
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: (sometimes without knowing that he does so) that nature is uniform and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: constant, that it will do to-day as it did yesterday, and does in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: infinite space as it does in the visible universe.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The knowledge that is possible to the empiricist, then, is merely that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: which is derived from direct experience, and simple summations or
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: generalisations into a single assertion of a number of similar
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: assertions, all of which were individually derived from experience. This
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is the position scientists as such, and believers in the theory of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: naturalism, take up as to the possibility of the knowledge of truth to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the human mind. They are entirely consistent, therefore, when they
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: arrive ultimately at the agnostic position, and contend that our
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: knowledge must necessarily be confined to the world of experience, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that nothing can be known of the world beyond. But they are
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: fundamentally wrong in overestimating the place of the sense organs, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: forgetting that while these have a part to play in life, they do not
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: constitute the whole of life.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: A far more satisfactory theory is that of _Rationalism_. It
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is a theory that admits that the human mind has some capacity for
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: working upon the data presented to it by the sense organs. Man is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: no longer quite so helpless a creature as empiricism would make
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: him. He is able to weigh and consider the facts that are presented
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to the mind. The method rationalism uses to arrive at truth is that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of logical deduction, and the test of truth is that the steps in the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: process are logically sound. We may start from the data "All dogs
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: are animals" and "Carlo is a dog," and arrive very simply at the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: conclusion "Carlo is an animal." The conclusion is correct because
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: we have reasoned in accordance with the laws of logic, with the laws
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of valid thought. All logical reasoning is, of course, not so simple
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: as the example given, but it may be stated generally that when there
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is no logical fallacy, a correct conclusion may be arrived at,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: provided, too--and herein lies the difficulty--provided that the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: premises are also true. These premises may be in themselves general
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: statements--how is their truth established? They may be, and often
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: are, the generalisations of the empirical sciences, and must then
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: possess the same degree of uncertainty that these generalisations
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: possess. Some philosophers have contended that certain general ideas
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: are innate, but few would be found nowadays to accept such a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: contention. At other times mere definitions of terms may serve as
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: premises. One might state as a premise the definition "A straight
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: line is the shortest distance between two points," and the further
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: statement that "AB is a straight line between A and B," and conclude
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that the line AB represents the shortest distance between two points A
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and B. In a manner similar to this Euclid built his whole mathematical
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: system upon the basis of definitions and postulates, a system the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: complexity and thoroughness of which has caused all students of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: mathematics at one time or another to marvel and admire. But, of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: course, a definition is little more than assigning a definite term to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: a definite thing. It is when we begin to consider the premises that are
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: necessary for arriving at the profound truths of the universe that we
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: find the weakness of rationalism. How are we going to be provided with
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: premises for this end? Shall we begin by saying "There is a God" or
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: "There is no God"? How is the pure reasoning faculty to decide upon the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: premises in the matter of the great Beyond? We may weigh the arguments
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: for and against a certain position, and we may think that the probability
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: lies in a certain direction, but to decide finally and with certainty
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: by mere cold logical reasoning is impossible. We may bring out into
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: prominence through logical reasoning truths that were previously only
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: implicit, but to arrive at absolute truth with regard to the invisible
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: world, through intellect alone, has long been admitted to be an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: impossibility. The illusion of those who would believe that truth which
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: was not already implied in the premises could ever be obtained by mere
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: intellectual reasoning has long since been dispelled.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Perhaps it comes as a shock to the reader who has always insisted upon a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: clear intellectual understanding and a rigid reasoning upon all things,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to find within what narrow limits, after all, the intellect itself has
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to work--it can do little more than make more or less certain
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: generalisations concerning the world of experience, and then to argue
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: from these, or from definitions that it itself has framed. Of course
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: some of the ancient philosophers did try through a course of rigid
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: reasoning to solve the great problems, and for a long time it was
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: customary to expect that all philosophers should proceed in the same
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: way.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Modern philosophers, of whom William James, Bergson, and Eucken are
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: conspicuous examples, have appreciated the futility of such a task, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: have sought other means of solving the problem. The mistake in the past
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: has been to forget that the intelligence is but one aspect of human
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: life, and that the experience of mankind is far more complicated a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: matter than that of mere intellect, and not to be solved by intellect
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: alone. Intellect has to play a definite part in human life, but it does
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: not constitute the whole of life. Life itself is far greater than
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: intellect, and to live is a far more important thing than to know. The
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: great things are life and action; knowledge is ultimately useful in so
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: far as it contributes to the development of life and the perfection of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: action. Philosophers have for too long a period made knowledge an aim in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: itself, and have neglected to take proper account of the experiences of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: mankind. Their intellectual abstractions have tended to leave actual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: life more and more out of consideration, with the result that they have
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: been baffled at every turn. The more we think about it, the more we
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: become convinced that the mysterious universe in which we live will only
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: divulge just enough of its secrets to enable us to act, and this it
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: gives us with comparatively little trouble on our part. If we consider
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: an ordinary piece of wood, we find it is hard and offers a certain
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: resistance, and our knowledge of these elementary facts enables us to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: put it to use, but we shall never really solve the mysteries of its
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: formation and growth. These lead of course to very interesting
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: speculations, but their solution seems to be as far off as ever. We can
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: know little but that which we require for life. The making of life and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: action the basis of truth rather than trusting to the intellect alone,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is the great new departure in modern philosophy.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: One of the theories of knowledge that springs from laying emphasis upon
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: life and action is that of _Pragmatism_, of which the late Professor
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: William James was one of the greatest exponents. Pragmatists contend
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that the test of truth is its value for life--if the fact obtained is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the most useful and helpful for life, then it is the true one. Suppose
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: we are endeavouring to solve the great question, "Is there a God?" We
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: weigh the arguments for and against, but find it difficult to arrive at
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: a definite conclusion, because the arguments on both sides seem equally
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: plausible. How are we to decide? We cannot postpone the decision
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: indefinitely--we are forced to make a choice, for upon our decision
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: depends our aim and ideals in life. We are faced with a "forced option,"
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and must choose one or the other. We ask ourselves the question, "Which
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: will be of the greatest help to our lives--to believe that there is, or
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that there is not a God?" and we decide or will to believe the option
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that will help life most. It is a striking theory, but space forbids our
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: discussing it in detail.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The position Eucken adopts is that of _Activism_. In common with
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: pragmatism it makes truth a matter of life and action rather than of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: mere intellect, and considers fruitfulness for action a characteristic
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of truth. He differs from the pragmatic position in that he contends
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that truth is something deeper than mere human decision, that truth is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: truth, not merely because it is useful, that reality is independent of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: our experience of it, and that truth is gained intuitively through a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: life of action.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The riddle of the universe is solved for Eucken through life and action.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: While continual contemplation and thought is apt to paralyse us, "action
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is the best defensive weapon against the dangers and trials of human
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: existence." "Doubt is not cured by meditation, but by action." He
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: believes that we can attain certainty through action of much that cannot
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: be justified on rational grounds. If we wish to understand the vital
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: truths of life we must concentrate our souls on a good purpose--the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: activity that follows will bring its revelation. The problems of life
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: are solved by the life process itself. By acting in a certain way, man
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: comes into intimate relationship with the great reality of life, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: then he comes to know, not so much _about_ reality, as _within_ reality.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The ant in whom such complex instincts are developed, knows probably
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: nothing at all _about_ its little world, but knows everything necessary
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: _within_ its little world. It does not err, it does the right thing at
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the right time, and that because it is in tune with its universe, hence
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: acts from pure instinct in the right way. If intellect were to enter
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: into the case, its actions might become less reliable, and it would
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: blunder far oftener. In the case of man, his thinking capacity often
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: militates against successful instinctive and habitual actions--the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: moment we start to consider, we hesitate and are lost. In the same way,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: if the soul of man is brought into tune with the great reality, it has
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: but to act, and though it may never know all _about_ reality and be able
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to frame abstract theories of the universe, still it may know _with_ or
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: _within_ reality, and be thus enabled to act in the best way under
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: various circumstances. This is the theory of activism; it lays great
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: stress upon action, and upon intuition through action, and while it does
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: not ignore the intellect, it holds that when the intellect fails there
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is a possibility of the practical problem of life being solved through a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: life of action, when life is directed towards the highest ideals. The
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: danger of an activistic position, of course, is to undervalue the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: reasoning powers of man. Some critics hold that Eucken does this; the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: reader must judge for himself, but in doing so it will be well to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: remember that before trusting to intuitive revelation, Eucken demands
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the setting of one's face towards the highest and best.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: In the next chapter we can follow Eucken in his search for the great
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: reality in life.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: CHAPTER IV
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: THE PAST, PRESENT, AND THE ETERNAL
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: In investigating the problem of human life, Eucken lays great stress
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: upon the history of man in past ages--this is one of the special aspects
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of his philosophy. The fact is, of course, not surprising; he who would
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: explain the life of man would be unwise to ignore the records of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: past life of the human race. The thinker who examines the present only,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is apt to be narrow in his ideas, to fail to look upon events in their
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: proper perspective, and to be unduly affected by the spirit of the age
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in which he lives--the student of history avoids these pitfalls.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Moreover, man does not become aware of the depth of his own soul, until
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: he has "lived into" the experience of the past. This is what the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: profound investigator of history does; he lives again the life of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: hero, he feels with him as he felt upon special occasions, and in this
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: way there is revealed to him a profundity and greatness of human
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: experience, of which he would have been largely unaware if he had
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: trusted to his own experience alone, and to the superficial examination
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: he is able to make of the experiences of those living men with whom he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: comes into contact. In this way he is able in a sense to appropriate the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: experience of the greatest personalities unto himself, and enrich
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: considerably the contents of his own soul.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Through a study of history, too, we become aware of the intimate
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: connection that exists between the present and the past. The present
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: moment is a very transient thing; its roots are in the past, its hopes
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in the future. "If all depends on the slender thread of the fleeting
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: moment of the present, which illumines and endures merely for a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: twinkling of an eye, but to sink into the abyss of nothingness, then all
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: life would mean a mere exit into death.... Without connection there is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: no content of life." We are apt to look on the past as something dead,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: but it exists in living evidence in our souls to-day. It oppresses us or
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: stimulates us to action, it tyrannises over us or inspires us to higher
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: things. It has been customary to look upon the past as irrevocable.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Recent writers, of whom Maeterlinck and Eucken are striking instances,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: have endeavoured to show how the past can be remoulded and changed. The
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: past depends upon what we make of it to-day; if we despise our evil
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: conduct in former days, then the past itself is changed and conquered.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The mistake that is made is to regard the past as a thing complete in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: itself; what appears to be finished is really only completing itself,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and we must take a view of the whole of a thing, and not merely the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: parts that have already manifested themselves. Through such
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: considerations we become more and more aware of the ultimate connection
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: between the past and present, and of the part the present can play in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the remaking of the past.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Our investigations of history leads us, too, to differentiate between
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the temporary and the eternal in the realm of thought. We find at a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: certain period of history a trend of thought that can largely be
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: accounted for by the special conditions of life at the time, and which
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: disappears at a later age. But in addition to this we become aware of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: truths that have found a place in the thoughts of various ages and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: countries, and we are led to regard these as the eternal
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: truths--expressions of an eternal ever-present reality. This eternal
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: present we find to be something independent of time, something that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: breaks the barriers between the past, present, and future. "Thought,"
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: says Eucken, "does not drift along with time; as certainly as it strives
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to attain truth it must rise above time, and its treatment must be
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: timeless." The beliefs of any age are too much coloured by the special
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: circumstances of that age to express the whole of truth, yet beneath the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: beliefs of the ages there is often an underlying truth, and this
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: underlying truth is the eternal truth, which is not affected by time,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and at the basis of which is the eternal reality.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: This eternal truth persisting through a variety of temporary and more or
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: less correct expressions of it is to be observed in a marked manner in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the moral ideas of mankind. What a variety of ethical doctrines have
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: been expounded and believed, yet how striking the similarity that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: becomes apparent when they are further examined! In practice, the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: standard of morality has often been based on mere utility, but it has
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: taken a higher and more absolute basis in the mind of man. Ideas
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: concerning morality have generally been nobler than can be accounted for
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: by environment, and by the subjective life of the individual. Why this
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: ultimate consistency in the moral aspirations of the ages, why a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: categorical imperative, and why does conscience exist in the human
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: being?--these facts cannot be accounted for if there is no deeper basis
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: for life than the life of humanity at any definite period of time.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The unchangeable laws of logic, too, are instances of the eternal truth.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The principles of the validity of thought are entirely independent of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: individuals, of the passage of time, and of the environment of man. "Our
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: thought cannot advance in the definite work of building up science
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: without producing and employing a definite logical structure, with fixed
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: principles; these principles are immanent in the work of thought, they
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: are above all the caprice and all the differences of the individuals."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Whence again this consistency in a changeable and subjective world?
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The marvellous influence that ideas have exerted upon man again points
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to the persistence and power of the eternal. Is it not strange how it is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that man often serves but as a mere instrument for the realisation of an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: idea, and how he is often carried away by an idea to do things which are
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: against his own personal interests and desires? And when he and his
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: generation have passed beyond human sight, we often find a new
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: generation direct their endeavours in the same way, and we wonder what
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is behind such a continuity in the struggles of mankind.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The history of great personalities in the realms of literature, art, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: science show in a remarkable way how men have risen above the influences
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of their time, and beyond the cramping tiredness of the mere flesh.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Could a great thinker like Aristotle be entirely conditioned by flesh
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and environment? And what of the great artists and poets who have
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: conquered the chains of mortal finitude and breathed of higher worlds?
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Every one of them is a convincing testimony of the possibility of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: mankind transcending the material, and taking unto itself of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: resources of a deeper world.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Then the dissatisfaction of the ages with their limited knowledge of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: truth cannot but tell of a great eternal something that stirs at the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: basis of the human soul. The people of to-day find the various systems
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of the day inadequate; they search for something higher, and the mere
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: fact that they search beyond matter and the mere subjective human
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: qualities is in itself a testimony to the existence of a world higher
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: than the material and subjective.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: What is it that makes it possible for one human being to "live into" the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: experience of others who lived long ago, and for the present to conquer
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and alter the past? How can we account for the eternal trait in thought,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: for the unchanging laws of logic, for the consistency of moral ideals,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and their transcendence over flesh and immediate circumstances? What is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the force behind the idea, and how can we account for the continuous
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: struggle of mankind in certain directions? And, finally, what is it that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: makes it possible for men to rise beyond themselves, to shake away the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: shackles of matter and vicinity, and to delve deep into the profounder
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: world?
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: If we can find what it is that makes all this possible, then surely we
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: have found the greatest thing in the world--the reality. And Eucken's
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: answer is clear and definite. It must be something that persists, is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: eternal and independent of time, and it must extend beyond the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: individual to a universal whole. This must be "the Universal Spiritual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Life," which, though eternal, reveals itself in time, and though
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: universal, reveals itself in the individual man, and forms the source
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: from which the spiritual in man "draws its power and credentials."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: This, then, is the result of Eucken's search for reality--he has found
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: it to exist in a Universal Spiritual Life. Of course he has not arrived
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: at his conclusion by a system of rigid proof; it has already been
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: pointed out how impossible it is to arrive at the greater truths of life
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in such a manner.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: He has done, however, that which can be reasonably expected in such
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: cases. To begin with, he has given us a striking analysis of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: essential characteristics of human life, and he has found there a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: yearning and a void. He has given us a masterly discussion of eternal
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: truth as contrasted with the temporary expressions of it. He has taught
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: us how the present can overcome the past, and how man can ascend beyond
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the subjective and material. And he has led us to feel that reality must
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: lie in the eternal that appears to be at the basis of the highest and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: greatest in man.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Moreover, he has given a fair and thorough treatment of the solutions
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that have been offered in the past. He has shown how inadequate they are
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to explain life. He has shown how the modern solutions "cannot perform
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: their own tasks without drawing incessantly upon another kind of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: reality, one richer and more substantial." This in itself shows "beyond
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: possibility of refutation that they do not fill the whole of life." He
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: has demonstrated how the acceptance of these systems depends upon an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: implicit acceptance of a higher life. "The naturalistic thinker ascribes
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)
