text: unperceived to nature, which to him can be only a coexistence of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: soulless elements, an inner connection and a living soul. Only thus can
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: he revere it as a higher power, as a kind of divinity; only thus can he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: pass from the fact of dependence to a devotional surrender of his
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: feelings. The socialist bases human society, with its motives mixed with
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: triviality and passion, on an invisible community, an ideal humanity....
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The individualist in his conception exalts the individual to a height
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: far more lofty than is justified by the individual as he is found in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: experience." All these assume more or less unconsciously the existence
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of that "something higher" which they attempt to deny.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: So far, then, we have seen how Eucken proves the inadequacy of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: realistic conceptions of life, and how they really depend for their
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: acceptance upon the assumption of a Universal Spiritual Life. We have
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: still to see how he attempts to prove that basing human life upon an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: eternal spiritual life satisfies the conditions he himself has laid down
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: for a satisfactory solution of the problem. He has to show that the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: theory gives a satisfactory explanation of human life, that it gives a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: firm basis for life, that it releases man from being governed by low
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: motives, and admits of the possibility of human personality, freedom,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and creation. We shall see in the chapters that follow that he makes a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: convincing case for accepting the belief in the Universal Spiritual Life
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: as the basis of human life and endeavour.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: THE "HIGH" AND THE "LOW"
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Eucken makes the recognition of the existence of a Universal Spiritual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Life the starting-point of his constructive work. He takes up a position
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: which he calls the noeological position. Many theories take up a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: materialistic position; they assert the reality of the material world,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and endeavour to explain the world of matter as something independent of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the human mind. Other theories assert the superiority of mind over
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: matter, and endeavour to examine the mind as though it were independent
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of the material world. These two types of theories have been in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: continual conflict; the one has attempted to prove that thought is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: entirely conditioned by sense impressions received from the material
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: world, the other regards the phenomena of nature as really nothing other
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: than processes of the mind.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Eucken finds reality existing in the spiritual life, which while neither
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: material nor merely mental, is superior to both, admits the existence
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: (in a certain sense) of both, and does away with the opposition between
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the rival types of theories. Eucken does not minimise or ignore the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: existence of the natural world. The question for him is not the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: independent existence of the worlds of nature and mind--this he admits;
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: he is concerned rather with the superiority of the spiritual life over
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the merely material and mental.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The natural life of man has been variously viewed in different ages. The
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: writer of the Pentateuch described man as made in the image of God, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the natural man was exalted on this account. Some of the old Greek
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: philosophers, too, found much in nature that was divine. Christianity
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: took a different view of the matter--it exalted the spirit, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: emphasised the baseness of the material. The growth of the sciences made
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: man again a mere tool of laws and methods, but it considered matter as
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: superior to mind, mind being entirely dependent upon impressions
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: received from matter. The question continually recurs--which is the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: high, which is the low? Shall nature triumph over spirit, or spirit over
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: nature?
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Pantheism replies to the question by denying that there is anything high
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: as distinguished from the low. There is but one; and that one--the whole
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: universe--is God. There is no evil in the world, says pantheism,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: everything is good--if we could understand things as they really are we
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: should find no oppositions in the universe, and no contradictions in the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: nature of things. The world as it is, is the best of all possible
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: worlds--there is perfect harmony, though we fail to appreciate it. Other
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: optimistic theories, too, deny the existence of evil and pain, and try
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to explain our ideas of sin to be mere "points of view." If we could see
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the whole, they tell us, we should see how the parts harmonise, but now
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: we only see some of the parts and fail to appreciate the harmony. In
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: this way they try to explain away as unreal the phenomena of evil and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: pain.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: But Eucken has no patience with such theories. For him the oppositions
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and contradictions of life are too real and persistent. The antagonisms
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: "stir us with disgust and indignation." Evil cannot be considered
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: trivial, and must not be glossed over; it is in the world, and the more
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: deeply we appreciate the fact the better it will be for the human soul.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Man in his lower stages of development is just a child of nature, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: his standards of life are those of the lower world. He seeks those
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: things that satisfy the senses, he attempts the satiation of the lower
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: cravings. In the realm of morals his standard is utility--that is good
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: which helps him to obtain more pleasure and to avoid pain. In social
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: life his conduct is dictated by custom--this is the highest appeal. The
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: development of man along the lines of nature ends at this point--and if
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: nothing more is to happen, then he must remain at a low level of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: development. Matter and mind cannot take him beyond--the mind as such
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: only helps towards the further satisfaction of the lower demands of man.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: But there is something far greater in highly developed manhood than the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: petty and selfish. Man is capable of conceiving and adopting higher
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: standards of morality than those of utility and pleasure, and it is the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: spiritual life that enables him to do this. It is the spiritual that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: frees the individual from the slavery of the sense world--from his
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: selfishness and superficial interests--that teaches him to care less for
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the things of the flesh, and far more for the beautiful, the good, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the true, and that enables him to pursue high aims regardless of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: fact that they may entail suffering and loss in other directions. This,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: then, is the "High" in the world; the natural life is the "Low."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: But what is the relation of the natural to the spiritual life? In the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: first place, the spiritual cannot be derived from the natural, inasmuch
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: as the former is immensely superior to the latter, and that not merely
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in degree, but in its very essence. The spiritual is entirely on a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: higher plane of reality, and there cannot be transition from the natural
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to the spiritual world. The natural has its limitations, and beyond
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: these cannot go. So far as the natural world is concerned man can never
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: rise above seeking for pleasure, and making expediency and social
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: approbation the standards of life, hence there is little wonder that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: those ethical teachers who make nature their basis, deny the possibility
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of action that is unselfish and free. "The Spiritual Life," however, as
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Eucken says, "has an independent origin, and evolves new powers and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: standards."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Neither do the two aspects run together in life in parallel lines. On
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the contrary, the spiritual life cannot manifest itself at all until a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: certain stage of development is reached in nature. It would seem
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: impossible to conceive of the animal rising above its animal instincts
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and tendencies; its whole life is conditioned by its animal nature and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: its environment. Man stands at the junction of the stages between the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: purely natural and the purely spiritual. On the one hand, he is a member
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of the animal world, he has its instincts, its desires and its
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: limitations; on the other hand, he has within him the germ of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: spirituality. He belongs to both worlds, the natural and the spiritual.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: He cannot shake off the natural and remain a man--to separate the two
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: means death to man as we know him. But there is a great difference
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: between his position in the natural world and his position in the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: spiritual world. He seems to be the last word in the world of nature, he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: has reached heights far beyond those reached by any other flesh and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: blood. He is, so far as we know, the culminating point of natural
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: evolution--the final possibility in the natural world. But the stage of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: nature only represents the first stage in the development of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: universe.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: There is an infinitely higher stage of life, the spiritual life. And if
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: man is the final point of progress in the world of nature, he is, in his
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: primitive state, only at the threshold of the spiritual world. But he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is not an entire stranger to the spiritual--the germ is in him, and the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: spiritual is consequently not an alien world for him. If the spiritual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: were something entirely foreign it would be vain to expect much progress
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: through mere impulses from without. On the contrary, it is the spiritual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that makes man really great, and is the most fundamental part of his
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: nature.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The two stages of life, then, are present in man--the natural and the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: spiritual; the former highly developed, the latter, at first, in an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: undeveloped state.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Now the great aim of the universe is to pass gradually from the natural
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to the spiritual plane of life. This does not mean that the latter is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the product of the former stage, for this is not the case. It means that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the deeper reality in life is the spiritual, and that the spiritual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: develops through the natural in its own particular way. And this
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: particular way is not a mere development but a _self_-development. The
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: aim of the spiritual is to develop its own self through the human being.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: In this way man is given the possibility of developing a self--a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: personality in a very real sense.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Thus we arrive at some idea of the relation there exists between the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: spiritual and the natural, and of the place of the spiritual and the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: natural in man. The spiritual is neither the product nor an attribute of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the natural. Man is the border creature of the two worlds; he represents
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the ultimate possibility of the one, and possesses potentialities in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: regard to the other. The great object of his life must be to develop,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: through making use of and conquering the life of nature, his higher self
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: into a free, spiritual, and immortal personality. The progressive stages
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in this direction must be dealt with in the next chapter.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: CHAPTER VI
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: THE ASCENT TO FREEDOM AND PERSONALITY
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: In the previous chapter we found that man in his primitive stage is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: largely a creature of the lower world. His desires are those of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: animal kingdom, his ideal is utility, and social approbation his God. At
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: this stage he is a mere nothing, no better than a slave to his passions
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and to the opinions of his fellow-beings. He possesses neither freedom
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: nor personality--for he is but a tool in the hands of other impulses and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: forces. There is no controlling self--he is not a lord in his own
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: kingdom. Some men do not get beyond this very low level, but for ever
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: remain mere shuttlecocks driven hither and thither by more or less
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: contradictory impulses.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The germ of the higher world that resides within him may sometimes make
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: itself felt, but "so long as there is a confused welter of higher and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: lower impulses, ... so long is there an absence of anything essentially
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: new and lofty."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Man's aspirations for things that are higher, are at the outset very
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: sluggish and vague, for a being that is so much dominated by the natural
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: world is apt to concentrate its attention upon it and to remain
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: contented with it.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: But there comes a time in the lives of perhaps most men when a distinct
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: feeling of dissatisfaction is felt with the life of natural impulse and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of convention. The man feels--perhaps in a vague way at first--that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: there is something too merely animal in the sense world, or that there
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is an intolerable emptiness and hypocrisy in a life of slavish devotion
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to the opinions of society. Perhaps he feels that his passions govern
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: him, and not he his passions. The higher life stirs within him, and he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: begins to question the rightness of things. He learns to appreciate for
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the first time that the natural impulses may not be the noblest, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that custom may not be an ideal guide. His soul is astir with the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: problem of life--the result very largely depends upon the solutions that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: are presented to him. Perhaps the naturalistic solution is made to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: appeal to him, and he is taught to trust nature and it will lead him
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: aright. Or maybe the pantheistic theory is accepted by him, and he is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: led to believe that the world as it is is entirely good, and that he has
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: but to live his life from day to day, and not worry himself about the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: ultimate end and purpose of things. Or other optimistic theories of life
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that deny the existence of evil may influence him. All these solutions
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: may give him temporary peace of mind, and perhaps indeed form efficient
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: stumbling-blocks to any further spiritual progress.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: But the spiritual beginnings within us often show remarkable vitality.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: They may under certain conditions lead us to appreciate the existence of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: a distinct opposition in the world--the opposition between the lower
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: world and the higher self. Man finds that the natural is often low,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: evil, and sordid, and at this stage the higher spiritual world makes a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: strong appeal to him. By degrees he comes to feel the demands of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: lower world to be a personal insult to him. What is the lower material
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: world that it should govern him, and he a _man_? The claims of pleasure
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and utility to be standards of conduct strike him as arrogant, and he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: revolts against the assumption that higher aims can have no charm for
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: him. His previous acceptance without consideration of the moral
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: standard of the community he now looks upon as a sign of weakness on his
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: part--for is he not himself, a person with the power of independent
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: judgment and evaluation? It is the first great awakening of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: spiritual life in man, when his whole soul is in revolt against the low,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: sordid, and conventional. What shall he do? There is only one course
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that is worthy of his asserting personality--he must break with the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: world. Henceforth he sees two worlds in opposition--the world of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: flesh on the one hand, the world of the spirit on the other, and he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: arrays himself on the side of the higher in opposition to the lower.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: When he does this the spiritual life in him makes the first substantial
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: movement in its onward progress--this movement Eucken calls the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: _negative movement_. It does not mean that the man must leave the world
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of work and retire into the seclusion of a monastery--that means
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: shirking the fight, and is a policy of cowardice. Neither does it mean a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: wild impatience with the present condition of the world--it means rather
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that man is appreciating in a profound way the oppositions that exist,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and is casting his lot on the side of right. He renounces everything
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that hinders him from fighting successfully, then goes forth into the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: thick of the battle. The break must be a definite one and made in a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: determined manner. "Without earnestness of renunciation the new life
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: sinks back to the old ... and loses its power to stimulate to new
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: endeavour. As human beings are, this negation must always be a sharp
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: one."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The negative movement, then, is the first substantial step in the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: progress of the spiritual life. The man's self breaks out into
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: discontent with nature, and this is the first step to the union of self
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to the higher reality in life. The break with the world is in itself of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: course but a negative process. This must attain a positive significance.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: If the self breaks away from one aspect of life, it must identify itself
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: more intimately with another. This occurs when the individual sets out
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: definitely on a course of life in antagonism to the evil in the world.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: When this takes place, there arises within him a _new immediacy_ of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: experience. Hitherto the things that were his greatest concern, and that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: appealed to him most, were the pleasures of the natural world. But these
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: things appeal to him no longer as urgent and immediate--but as being of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: a distinctly secondary character. A new immediacy has arisen; it is the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: facts of the spiritual world that now appeal to him as urgent and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: immediate. "All that has hitherto been considered most immediate, as the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: world of sense, or even the world of society, now takes a second place,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and has to make good its claim before this spiritual tribune.... That
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: which current conceptions treat as a Beyond ... is now the only world
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: which exists in its own right, the only true and genuine world which
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: neither asks nor consents to be derived from any outside source."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: This new immediacy is the deepest possible immediacy, it is an immediacy
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of experience where the self comes into contact with its own vital
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: principle--the Universal Spiritual Life--and brings about a fundamental
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: change in the life of the individual. The inner life is no longer
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: governed by sense impressions and impulses, but the outward life is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: lived and viewed from the standpoint of the inward life.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: But a new immediacy is not all that follows in the train of the negative
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: movement--on the contrary, the highest possible rewards are gained, for
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: freedom, personality, and immortality are all brought within the range
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of possibility.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Once a human being decides for the highest he is on the highroad to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: complete freedom. The freedom is not going to be won in a moment, but
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: must be fought for by the individual through the whole course of his
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: life. His body is always with him, and will at times attempt to master
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: him--he must fight continually to ensure conquest. Difficulties will
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: arise from various quarters, but he is not going to depend only upon his
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: own resources. All his activity involves in the first place the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: recognition of the spiritual world, but more than this, he appropriates
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: unto himself of the spiritual world--this in itself is an act of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: decision. And the more we appropriate unto ourselves of the Universal
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Spiritual Life, the more we decide for the higher world, the freer we
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: become. Indeed, "it is this appropriation ... of the spiritual life that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: first awakens within the soul an inward certitude, and makes possible
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that perfect freedom ... so indispensable for every great creative
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: work." By continually choosing and fighting for the progress of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Universal Spiritual Life, it comes to be our own in virtue of our deed
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and decision. Hence man has attained freedom--the lower world no longer
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: makes successful appeal. He has become a part of the spiritual world,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and his actions are no longer dictated by anything external, but are the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: direct outcome of his own self. He has freely chosen the highest, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: continually reaffirms his choice--this is perfect freedom.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Man gains for himself, too, a personality in the true sense of the term.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Eucken does not mean by personality "mere self-assertion on the part of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: an individual in opposition to others." He means something far deeper
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: than this. "A genuine self," says Eucken, "is constituted only by the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: coming to life of the infinite spiritual world in an independent
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: concentration in the individual." Following a life of endeavour in the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: highest cause, and continual appropriation of the spiritual life, he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: arrives at a state of at-one-ness with the universal life. "Man does not
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: merely enter into some kind of relation with the spiritual life, but
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: finds his own being in it." The human being is elevated to a self-life
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of a universal kind, and this frees him from the ties and appeals of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: world of sense and selfishness. It is a glorious conception of human
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: personality, infinitely higher than the undignified conceptions of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: naturalism and determinism.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: And if man wins a glorious personality, he may gain immortality too.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Unfortunately, Eucken has not yet dealt fully with this question, but he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is evidently of the opinion that the spiritual personalities are
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: immortal. As concentration points or foci of the spiritual life, he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: believes that the developed personalities are at present and in prospect
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: possessors of a spiritual realm. But there will be no essential or
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: sudden change at death. That which is immortal is involved in our
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: present experience. Those who have developed into spiritual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: personalities, who have worked in fellowship with the great Universal
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Life, and become centre-points of spirituality, have thus risen supreme
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: over time and pass to their inheritance. Those who have not done so, but
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: have lived their lives on the plane of nature, will have nothing that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: can persist.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Hence it is that the negative movement leads to freedom, personality,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and immortality; the neglect to make the movement consigns the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: individual to slavery, makes a real "self" impossible, and at death he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: has nought that a spiritual realm can claim. The choice is an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: all-important one; for, as a recent writer puts it, "In this choice, the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: personality chooses or rejects itself, takes itself for its life-task,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: or dies of inanition and inertia."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

text: CHAPTER VII
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
