text: RELIGION: HISTORICAL AND ABSOLUTE
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: In examining the various historical forms of religion, Eucken, as we
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: should expect, is governed by the conclusions he has arrived at
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: concerning the solution of the great problem of life, and especially of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the place of religion in life.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: A religion which emphasised the need for a break with the world, and of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: fight and action for spiritual progress, the possibility of a new higher
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: life of freedom and of personality, and the superiority of the spiritual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: over the material, and which presented God as the ultimate spiritual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: life, in which the human personality found its real self, would thus
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: meet with highest favour, while a form of religion that failed to do so
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: would necessarily fail to satisfy the tests that he would apply.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: He does not spend time discussing various religions in detail, but deals
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: with them briefly in general, in order to show that the Christian
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: religion is far superior to all other religions, then he makes a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: critical and very able examination of the Christian position. He
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: considers it necessary to discuss in detail only that form of religion
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that is undoubtedly the highest.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The historical religions he finds to be of two types--religions of law
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and religions of redemption. The religions of law portray God as a being
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: outside the world, and distinct from man, One who rules the world by
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: law, and who decrees that man shall obey certain laws of conduct that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: He lays down. Failure to obey these laws brings its punishment in the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: present or in a future life, while implicit obedience brings the highest
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: rewards. To such a God is often attributed all the weaknesses of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: human being, sometimes in a much exaggerated form--hence His reign
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: becomes one of fear to His subjects.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: A religion of law assumes that man is capable of himself of obeying the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: law, and is responsible for his mode of life; it assumes that man is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: capable through his own energy of conquering the world of sin, and of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: leading the higher life.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Religions of this type possess of course the merit of simplicity,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: transparency, and finality. The decrees, the punishments and rewards are
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: given with some clearness and are easily understood; there is no appeal
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and little equivocation. They served a useful purpose in the earlier
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: ages of civilisation, but cannot solve the problem for the complex
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: civilisation and advanced culture of the present age. They place God too
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: far from man, and attribute to man powers which he cannot of himself
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: possess. The conceptions of the Deity involved in them are too
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: anthropomorphic in character--too much coloured by human frailties.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The religions of law have had to give place to those of a superior
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: type--the religions of redemption. These religions appreciate the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: difficulty there exists for humankind of itself to transcend the world
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of sin, and are of two types--one type expressing a merely negative
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: element, the other a negative and positive element.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The typical negative redemptive religion is that of Buddhism. Buddhism
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: teaches us that the world is a sham and an evil; and the duty of man is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to appreciate this fact, and to deny the world, but here the matter
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: ends--it ends with world-renunciation and self-renunciation. There is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: only a negative element in such a religion, no inspiration to live and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: fight for gaining a higher world. This, of course, cannot provide a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: satisfactory solution to the problem, for no new life with new values is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: presented to us. It is a religion devoid of hope, for it does not point
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to a higher life. "A wisdom of world-denial, a calm composure of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: nature, an entire serenity in the midst of the changing scenes of life,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: constitute the summit of life."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Christianity teaches us that the world is full of misery and suffering,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: but the world in itself is really a perfect work of Divine wisdom and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: goodness. "The root of evil is not in the nature of the world, but in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: moral wrong--in a desertion from God." Sin and wickedness arise from the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: misuse and perversion of things which are not in themselves evil.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Christianity calls for a break from the wickedness of the world. It
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: calls upon man to give up his sin, to deny, or break with, the evil of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: which he is guilty. But it does not expect man to do this in his own
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: strength alone--God Himself comes to his rescue. Unlike Buddhism, it
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: does not stay at the denial of the world, but calls upon man to become a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: citizen of a higher world. This gives a new impetus to the higher life;
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: man finds a great task--he has to build a kingdom of God upon the earth.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: This demands the highest efforts--he must fight to gain the new world,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and must keep up the struggle to retain what he has gained. The
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: inferiority of Buddhism as contrasted with Christianity is well
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: described by Eucken in the following words: "In the former an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: emancipation from semblance becomes necessary; in the latter an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: overcoming of evil is the one thing needful. In the former the very
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: basis of the world seems evil; in the latter it is the perversion of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: this basis which seems evil. In the former, the impulses of life are to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: be entirely eradicated; in the latter, on the contrary, they are to be
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: ennobled, or rather to be transformed. In the former, no higher world of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: a positive kind dawns on man, so that life finally reaches a seemingly
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: valid point of rest, whilst upon Christian ground life ever anew ascends
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: beyond itself."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: From such considerations as these, Eucken comes to the conclusion that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of the redemptive religions, which are themselves the highest type,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Christianity is the highest and noblest form, hence his main criticism
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is concerned with the Christian religion. This does not mean that he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: finds neither value nor truth in any other form of religion. His general
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: conclusion with regard to the historical religions is that they "contain
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: too much that is merely human to be valued as a pure work of God, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: yet too much that is spiritual and divine to be considered as a mere
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: product of man." He finds in them all some kernel of truth, or at least
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: a pathway to some part of truth, but contends that no religion contains
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the whole truth and nothing but the truth. "As certainly," he says, "as
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: there is only one sole truth, there can be only one absolute religion,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and this religion coincides entirely in no way with any one of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: historical religions."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Eucken's great endeavour in his discussion of the Christian religion is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to bring out the distinction between the eternal substance that resides
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in it and the human additions that have been made to it in different
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: ages, between the elements in Christianity that are essentially divine
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and those essentially human. Divested of its human colourings and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: accretions, Christianity presents a basis of Divine and eternal truth,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and this regarded in itself, can well claim to be the final and absolute
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: religion.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The conclusion he has come to with regard to the eternal truth as
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: contrasted with the temporary colourings of Christianity, with the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: essential as contrasted with the inessential, can best be outlined by
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: taking in turn some of the main tenets and characteristics of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Christian faith.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Eucken's conception of the negative movement is very much akin to the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Christian idea of _conversion_. The first stage is merely a movement
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: away from the world, but after a time, in the continuous process of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: negation, the negative movement attains a positive significance; when
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: this stage is arrived at Eucken would apply the term conversion. He
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: would not limit the negative movement to one act or to one point in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: time; the movement towards a higher world must be maintained--the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: sustaining of the negative movement being a test of the reality of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: conversion. The process of conversion is not a process to be passively
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: undergone, or to originate from without, but is a movement starting in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the depths of one's own being.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: As already pointed out, Eucken believes in _redemption_. The past is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: capable of reinterpretation and transformation, because we can view our
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: past actions in a new light and so change the whole, since the past is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: not a closed thing, definite in itself, but a part of an incomplete
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: whole. He considers, however, that the Christian doctrine of redemption
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: makes it too much a matter of God's mercy, instead of placing stress
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: upon the part that man himself must play. The possibility of redemption
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in his view follows from the presence and movement of the spiritual life
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in man, not merely from an act of the founder of Christianity, and he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: avers that while traditional Christianity emphasises the need for
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: redemption from evil, it does not emphasise sufficiently the necessary
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: elevation to the good life that must result.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Closely bound up with the Christian doctrine of redemption is that of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: _mediation_. Eucken believes that the Christian conception of mediation
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: resulted from the feeling of worthlessness and impotence of man, and the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: aspirations which yet burned within him after union with the Divine. The
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: idea of mediation bridges the gulf, "a mid-link is forged between the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Divine and the human, and half of it belongs to each side; both sides
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: are brought into a definite connection which could be found in no other
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: way." Eucken acknowledges that such a mediation seems to make access to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the Divine easier, gives intimacy to the idea of redemption, and offers
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: support for human frailty. But he points out that there is an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: intolerable anthropomorphism involved in the idea, that it removes the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Divine farther away from man, and that the union of Divine and human is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: held to obtain in one special case only--that of Christ. He urges that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in a religion of mediation, one or other, God or Christ, must be chosen
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: as the centre. "Concerning the decision there cannot be the least doubt;
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the fact is clear in the soul-struggles of the great religious
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: personalities, that in a decisive act of the soul the doctrinal idea of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: mediation recedes into the background, and a direct relationship with
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: God becomes a fact of immediacy and intimacy."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: So Eucken will have nothing to do with the idea of mediation in its
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: doctrinal significance--pointing out that "the idea of mediation glides
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: easily into a further mediation." "Has not the figure of Christ receded
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in Catholicism, and does not the figure of Mary constitute the centre of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the religious emotional life?"
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: He does, however, lay great store by the help that a man may be to other
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: men in their upward path: "The human, personality who first and foremost
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: brought eternal truth to the plane of time, and through this
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: inaugurated a new epoch, remains permanently present in the picture of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the spiritual world, and is able permanently to exercise a mighty power
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: upon the soul ... but all this is far removed from any idea of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: mediation."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Eucken believes in _revelation_, but through action, and not through
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: contemplation. To the personality struggling upward, with its aims set
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: towards the highest in life, the spiritual life reveals itself. He does
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: not confine revelation to certain periods in time, and believes that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: such revelation comes to all spiritual personalities.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: He holds, too, that the spiritual personalities are themselves
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: revelations of the Universal Spiritual Life, and that the Spiritual Life
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: does reveal itself most clearly in personalities.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: How the revelation comes he does not discuss in any detail, but he is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: very certain that it comes through action and fight for the highest.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: It is perhaps largely due to his activistic standpoint that Eucken does
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: not deal with _prayer_. In the _Truth of Religion_, which deals very
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: fully with most aspects of religion, and purports to be a complete
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: discussion of religion, no treatment of prayer is given. He speaks of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the developing personality as drawing upon the resources of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Universal Spiritual Life, but this appears to be in action, and not in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: prayer or communion.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: He is ever suspicious of intellectual contemplation, and this leads him
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to attribute less importance than perhaps he should to _mysticism_, to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: prayer, adoration, and worship. He admits that mysticism contains a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: truth that is vital to religion, but complains that it becomes for many
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the whole of religion. Its proper function is to liberate the human mind
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: from the narrowly human, and to emphasise a total-life, the great Whole.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: It fails, however, "because it turns this necessary portion of religion
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: into the sole content. To it, religion is nothing other than an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: absorption into the infinite and eternal Being--an extinguishing of all
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: particularity, and the gaining of a complete calm through the suspension
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of all the wear and tear of life."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Eucken's discussion of _faith and doubt_ is very illuminating. He
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: protests against the conception of faith which concerns itself merely
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: with the intellectual acceptance of this or that doctrine. This narrows
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and weakens its power, confining it to one department of life; whereas
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: faith is concerned with the whole of life.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Faith is for Eucken "a conviction of an axiomatic character, which
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: refuses to be analysed into reasons, and which, indeed, precedes all
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: reasons ... the recognition of the inner presence of an infinite
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: energy."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: If faith concerns itself with, and proceeds from the whole of life, it
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: will then take account of the work of thought, and will not set itself
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in opposition to reason. But it will lead where reason fails. It is not
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: limited by intellectual limitations, though it does not underrate or
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: neglect the achievements of the intellect. Faith enables life to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: "maintain itself against a hostile or indifferent world; ... it holds
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: itself fast to invisible facts against the hard opposition of visible
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: existence."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The vital importance of such faith to religion is clearly evident; and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: bound up with this is the significance of doubt. Doubt, too, becomes
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: now, not an intellectual matter, but a matter for the whole of life. "If
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: faith carries within itself so much movement and struggle, it is not
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: surprising ... if faith and doubt set themselves against each other, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: if the soul is set in a painful dilemma." Eucken considers it to be an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: inevitable, and indeed a necessary accompaniment of religious
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: experience, and his own words on the point are forcible and clear.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: "Doubt ... does not appear as something monstrous and atrocious, though
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: it would appear so if a perfect circle of ideas presented itself to man
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and demanded his assent as a bounden duty. For where it is necessary to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: lay hold on a new life, and to bring to consummation an inward
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: transformation, then a personal experience and testing are needed. But
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: no proof is definite which clings from the beginning to the final
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: result, and places on one side all possibility of an antithesis. The
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: opposite possibility must be thought out and lived through if the Yea is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to possess full energy and genuineness. Thus doubt becomes a necessary,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: if also an uncomfortable, companion of religion; it is indispensable for
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the conservation of the full freshness and originality of religion--for
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the freeing of religion from conventional forms and phrases."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Eucken's views on _immortality_ have already been dealt with. He does
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: not accept the Christian conception of it, for he seems to limit the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: possibility to those in whom spiritual personalities have been
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: developed, and he evidently does not believe that the "natural
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: individuality with all its egoism and limitations" is going to persist.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: In discussing the question of _miracle_, Eucken weighs the fact that a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: conviction of the possibility of miracle has been held by millions in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: various religions, and particularly in Christianity. He considers that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the question of miracle is of more importance in the Christian religion
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: than in any other, one miracle--the Resurrection--having been taken
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: right into the heart of Christian doctrine. He finds, however, that the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: miracle is entirely inconsistent with an exact scientific conception of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: nature, and means "an overthrow of the total order of nature as this
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: has been set forth through the fundamental work of modern
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: investigation." He does not consider such a position can be held without
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: overwhelming evidence, and does not feel the traditional fact to have
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: this degree of certainty, or to be inexplicable in another way. He
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: considers that the explanation of the miracle probably lies in the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: psychic state of the witnesses.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Eucken shows in general extreme reluctance to make a historical event a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: foundation of belief, and this no doubt accounts to some extent for his
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: attitude with regard to miracles. He points out that "the founders of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: religion have themselves protested against a craving after sensuous
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: signs," and that this protest "is no other than the sign of spiritual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: power and of a Divine message and greatness." He considers that the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: belief in, and craving for, sensuous miracle is an outcome of a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: "mid-level of religion," where belief is waning and spirituality
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: declining. While, thus, he does not believe in sensuous miracle, he
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: acknowledges and lays the greatest stress on one miracle--the presence
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of the Spiritual Life in man. It is, indeed, this miracle that renders
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: others unnecessary.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: In discussing the doctrine of the _Incarnation_, Eucken attempts to get
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: at the inner meaning--the truth which the doctrine endeavours to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: express, and he finds this to consist in the fact of the ultimate union
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of the human and Divine, and this truth is one that we dare not
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: renounce. He criticises the attempt that is made in Christianity to show
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: that such union only obtained once in the course of history. Incarnation
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is not one historical event, but a spiritual process; not an article of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: belief, but a living experience of each spiritual personality.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: He considers as injurious to religion in general the Christian
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: conception of the _Atonement_. He believes that the idea that is to be
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: expressed is that of the nearness of God to man in guilt and in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: suffering. In endeavouring to express this close intimacy the idea of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: suffering was transferred to God himself. The anthropomorphic idea of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: reconciliation and substitution thus arose, and this Eucken considers to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: have done harm. "The notion that God does not help us through His own
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: will and power, but requires first of all His own feeling of pity to be
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: roused, is an outrage on God and a darkening of the foundation of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: religion." So Eucken objects to the attempt to formulate the mystery
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: into dogma. "All dogmatic formulation of such fundamental truths of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: religion becomes inevitably a rationalism and a treatment of the problem
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: by means of human relationships, and according to human standards." "It
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: is sufficient for the religious conviction to experience the nearness of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: God in human suffering, and His help in the raising of life out of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: suffering into a new life beyond all the insufficiency of reason.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Indeed, the more intuitively this necessary truth is grasped, the less
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: does it combine into a dogmatic speculation and the purer and more
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: energetically is it able to work."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The conception of the _Trinity_ is again an attempt to express the union
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of Divine and human, "the inauguration of the Divine Nature within human
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: life." The dogma, however, involves ideas of a particular generation,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and so threatens to become, and has indeed become, burdensome to a later
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: age which no longer holds these ideas. Further, the doctrine of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Trinity has mixed up a fundamental truth of religion with abstruse
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: philosophical speculations, and this has provided a stumbling-block
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: rather than a help.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: At the same time, Eucken lays the greatest stress on the _personality of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Jesus_. He considers the personality of Jesus to be of more importance
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: to Christianity than is the personality of its founder to any other
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: religion. "Such a personality as Jesus is not the mere bearer of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: doctrines, or of a special frame of mind, but is a convincing fact, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: proof of the Divine life, a proof at which new life can be kindled over
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: anew." And again: "It is from this source that a great yearning has been
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: implanted within the human breast ... a longing for a new life of love
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and peace, of purity and simplicity. Such a life, with its incomparable
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: nature and its mysterious depths, does not exhaust itself through
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: historical effects, but humanity can from hence ever return afresh to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: its inmost essence, and can strengthen itself ever anew through the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: certainty of a new, pure, and spiritual world over against the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: meaningless aspects of nature and over against the vulgar mechanism of a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: culture merely human." But while he would appreciate the depth and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: richness of the personality of Jesus, he protests against the worship of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Jesus as divine, and the making of Him the centre of religion. The
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: greatness of Christ is confined to the realm of humanity, and there is
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in all men a possibility of attaining similar heights.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Christianity is, in Eucken's view, much more closely bound up with
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: historical events than any other religion, and it thus suffers more
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: severe treatment at the hands of historical criticism than any other
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: religion. Eucken considers such historical criticism to be of great
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: value. In Christianity as in other religions we find the eternal not in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: its pure form, but mixed with the temporal and variable, and historical
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: criticism will help in the separation of the temporal from the eternal
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: elements. In so doing it does an immense service, for it frees religion
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: from fixation to one special point of time, and enables us to regard it
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: as ever developing and progressing to greater depths.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Eucken emphasises that the _historical basis_ of Christianity is not
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Christianity itself, is not essentially religious; and he quotes
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Lessing, Kant, and Fichte to support him in his contention that a belief
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in such a historical basis is not necessary to religion, and may even
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: prove harmful to it. The historical basis is, of course, useful as
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: bringing out into clear relief the personality of Jesus, and the other
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: great spiritual personalities associated in His work, and Eucken lays
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: stress upon the use that history can be to Christianity in giving
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: records of the experiences of great spiritual personalities in all ages,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: but it is important that the history is here a means to an end, and not
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: an end in itself, and that the importance lies in the spiritual
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: experience and not in the historical facts.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: When one considers how little Eucken has to say concerning worship, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: how little emphasis he places upon historical and doctrinal forms in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: religion, one wonders how it is he attaches so much importance to the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: functions of the _Church_. He points out that a Church is necessary to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: religion, that it seems to be the only way of making religion real and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: effective for man. "The Church seems indispensable in order to introduce
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and to hold at hand the new world and the new life to man in the midst
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of his ordinary existence; it is indispensable in order to fortify the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: conviction and to strengthen the energy in the midst of all the opposite
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: collisions; it is indispensable in order to uphold an eternal truth and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: a universal problem in the midst of the fleetingness of the moment." In
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the past, however, much harm has been done to religion by the Church.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: This has arisen from several reasons. To begin with, it tends to narrow
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: religion, which is concerned with life, to the realm of ideas, and to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: tie down religion by connecting it with a thought-system of a particular
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: age. Further, the necessary mechanical routine, and the appointment of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: special persons to carry out this routine, tends to elevate the routine
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and these special persons to a far higher place than they should occupy.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Again, spiritual things have been dragged into the service of personal
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: ambition, and bound up with human interests. The most serious danger,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: however, is that religion, from being an inward matter, tends to become
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: externalised.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Despite this, an organised Church cannot be dispensed with, and Eucken
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: points out what changes are necessary to make the Church effective. One
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: important point he makes clear, namely, that as the Church must speak to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: all, and every day, and not only to spiritually distinguished souls, and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: in moments of elevated feeling, then the teaching of the Church will
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: always lag behind religion itself, and must be considered as an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: inadequate expression of it.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: It is necessary that there should be no coercion with regard to men's
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: attitude towards the Church, and men should be free to join this or that
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Church, or no Church at all.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

text: Eucken's _appreciation of Christianity_ is sincere. Viewing it from the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

text: conditions that religion should fulfil. It is based on freedom, and on
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: the presence of the Divine in humanity, even to the extent of a complete
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: union between them. The ideal of the Christian life is a personal life
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of pure inwardness, and of an ethical character. He speaks of the "flow
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: religions," and of the "unfathomable depth and immeasurable hope which
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

text: are contained in the Christian faith."
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: In Christianity the life of Christ has a value transcending all time,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: and is a standard by which to judge all other lives. There is, too, in
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: before any progress or development can take place.

author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: "There is no need of a breach with Christianity; it can be to us what a
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: historical religion pre-eminently is meant to be--a sure pathway to
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: truth, an awakener of immediate and intimate life, a vivid
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: At the same time, there are changes necessary in the form of
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Christianity, if it is to answer to the demands of the age, and be the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: Absolute Religion. It must be shorn of temporary accretions, and must
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: cast aside the ideas of any one particular age which have now been
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: superseded. No longer can it retain the primitive view of nature and the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: world which formerly obtained, no longer must it take up a somewhat
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: negative and passive attitude, but, realising that religion is a matter
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: of the whole life, must energetically work itself out through all
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: departments of life. It must remedy wrong, not merely endure it. It must
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: proceed from a narrow and subjective point of view to a cosmic one,
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: without at the same time losing sight of the fact that religion is an
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: inward and personal matter. It must take account to the full of the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: value of man as man, and of the possibilities latent in him, and take
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: account of his own activity in his salvation.
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: The Christian ideal of life must be a more joyous one, of greater
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: spiritual power, and the idea of redemption must not stop short at
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: redemption from evil, but must progress to a restoration to free and
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: self-determining activity. Since an absolute religion is based on the
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: spiritual life, the form in which it is clothed must not be too
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

text: rigid--life cannot be bound within a rigid creed. With its form modified
title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
author: Jones, Abel J. (Abel John)

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life

title: Rudolph Eucken : a philosophy of life
